headline.main: Reality of the H.M.O. System Doesn't Live Up to the Dream

docs.abstract: Article in ongoing series, After the Revolution, on effect of managed care on nation's health care system; even though managed care plans are entrenched in economy, enrolling 61 percent of population, they have lost luster as industry and as answer to nation's health care needs; while they have provided different way to pay for medical care, they have not offered better way to provide it; even though savings to large employers have been real, contributing significantly to current economic boom, they are likely to prove temporary since coverage has become more expensive for small businesses and self-employed and has shifted many consumers' concerns from cost to quality; recent New York Times poll finds 85 percent of Americans believe health care system needs fundamental change, compared with 90 percent in 1994 before Clinton Administration's health-reform plan died, and that although 68 percent say they are satisfied with quality of family's health care, 30 percent say they are not--up from 19 percent in 1994; percentage dissatisfied with cost of health care is practically unchanged at 46 percent; photo (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: At the start of the 90's, when employers' health insurance costs were surging 15 percent a year, the giant Sprint Corporation was quick to shift to health maintenance organizations and their businesslike management of medical care. Sprint's costs promptly stabilized. Today, its comprehensive benefit program stands as a model of what Congress and industry envisioned four years ago when they rejected President Clinton's health plan and left the health care system to the tides of the marketplace.

headline.main: Settlement May Be Near In 8 States' Tobacco Suits

docs.abstract: State attorneys general nationwide reoprtedly will be briefed on details of new proposal for settlement with tobacco industry; Washington State Atty Gen Christine A Gregoire says negotiators have three unresolved issues, including how to deal with smaller producers that do not take part in settlement (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: In a sign that a new tobacco settlement deal may be near, state attorneys general nationwide will be told this week about the details of a plan intended to resolve their lawsuits against the industry, lawyers familiar with those discussions said. The briefings, which are expected to begin midweek, are the strongest indication yet that negotiators representing eight states and four major cigarette makers have resolved most major differences between them, said those lawyers, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
